text.__SUMMARY__: Davis's round-eared bat (Lophostoma evotis) is a species of Central American bat in the family Phyllostomidae. It is found in Belize, Guatemala, Honduras, and southeastern Mexico.
text.Description:
Its ears are long with rounded tips.
Its fur is dark gray.
Its forearm length is 47–53 mm (1.9–2.1 in).
Individuals weigh approximately 20 g (0.71 oz).
Its dental formula is 2.1.2.31.1.3.3 for a total of 32 teeth.
text.Biology and ecology: It is both frugivorous and insectivorous.
text.Range and habitat:
It is endemic to Central America; its range includes Belize, Guatemala, Honduras, and Mexico.
It has only been documented in lowlands.
In Mexico, it has not been documented above 200 m (660 ft) above sea level.
text.Conservation:
As of 2018, it is evaluated as a least-concern species by the IUCN.
It meets the criteria for this classification because it has a wide geographic range and its range includes protected areas.
